bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Committee on Trips, November 4, 1952

div1.p: Hench requests permission from the Mayo Clinic Committee on Trips to attend the dedication of Camp Lazear, explaining his involvement with the preservation efforts. He has been invited by the Cuban government to speak at the ceremony.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Committee on Trips, November 4, 1952
div1.p:
Absence December 2, 3 and 4. I rediscovered Camp Lazear (which had been
“lost” for 40 years) in 1940 and have made many trips there in order to
interest the Cubans to preserve the Camp. Several times they have been on
the verge of memorializing it but the plans always fall through. The
various governments who made promises to me were voted or thrown out of
office. Their plans to go ahead with the job and finish it were decided
rather suddenly this spring. I had hoped that the dedication would
be held off until next spring but they have gone ahead, made the park,
put in streets and so on this summer and are hoping to dedicate it on
“Physicians Day” in Havana, December 3. I have been invited by the Cuban
government to attend and to speak at the dedication of the Camp.

This is no place to discuss the following but the Cubans need very much the
friendly approval of American medicine in this venture. I believe this can
properly be called a medical trip as the dedication is sponsored by the
Ministry of Health of Cuba and the correspondence to me comes from the agent
of the Ministry of Health, who is also a physician. I will fly both ways
and the absence will total only about three or four days - no more
